questions.text: Which of the following statements about the chromosomal abnormality identified in the karyotype is incorrect?

choices.text: Closed fist with overlapping of fingers
AFP and uE3 are increased and Beta hCG is reduced
AFP, uE3 and Beta hCG are reduced

questions.solution:
The chromosomal abnormality based on the given karyotype is Edward's syndrome.

The karyotype given is trisomy 18 and is suggestive of Edward's syndrome. The clinical features include micrognathia, low-set ears (Option A), prominent occiput, and rocker bottom feet. Prenatal ultrasound reveals fetal growth restriction and all the 3 markers, AFP, uE3 and BetahCG are reduced (Option D) in Edward's syndrome.

Other features include a clenched fist with overriding fingers (Option B), i.e. index finger overlapping the third and 5th finger overlapping the 4th, small fingernails, underdeveloped thumbs, short sternum, and club feet.

questions.text: A 3-year-old female is brought to OPD with features of hand wringing stereotyped movements, impaired language and communication development, breath-holding spells and deceleration of head growth after 6 months of age. Which of the following genes is associated with the above disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 3-year-old female with normal psychomotor development until 6 months followed by regression in development, stereotyped movements and microcephaly is suggestive of Rett syndrome. The gene associated with Rett syndrome is the MECP-2 gene.

Rett syndrome is a progressive condition predominantly seen in girls. It has an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance. The onset is after a few months of apparently normal development. Under the international classification of diseases, the tenth revision it falls under pervasive development disorder. The Diagnostic and statistical manual, 5th Edition (DSM-5) considers it an autism spectrum disorder, though there are marked differences between them.

Between the ages of 6 months to 2 years, affected children develop progressive encephalopathy. Other clinical features include stereotypic hand movements such as hand wringing, biting, or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination. Marked regression of all language skills and plateaued communicative and social skills can also be seen. Microcephaly develops as age progresses. Head circumference is normal at birth, but between the age of 6 months to 1 year, growth begins to decelerate. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases. 

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

Trofinetide is a synthetic analogue of the amino‐terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) designed to treat the core symptoms of Rett syndrome by potentially reducing neuroinflammation and supporting the synaptic function of the protein fragment glypromate (GPE). IGF-1 is produced by both major types of brain cells – neurons and glia; IGF-1 in the brain is critical for both normal development and response to injury and disease. Trofinetide has been shown to inhibit the production of inflammatory cytokines, inhibit overactivation of microglia and astrocytes, and increase the amount of available IGF-1 that can bind to IGF-1 receptors.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of cholelithiasis was rushed to the casualty with complaints of vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. Her erect abdomen X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 60-year-old female presenting with features of intestinal obstruction with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus. Rigler's triad is seen in gallstone ileus.

Gallstone ileus is caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation.

Plain radiographs demonstrate air-fluid levels consistent with a small bowel obstruction. Rigler's triad is seen in gallstone ileus. It includes:

  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia)
  • Ectopic gallstone (Radio-opaque shadow in the right iliac fossa)

The presence of 2/3 of these radiological signs is pathognomonic of gallstone ileus. Pneumobilia is seen because the fistula that permitted a stone to pass into the duodenum allows air into the gallbladder and the biliary tree and is also a common finding following ERCP.

The investigation of choice is the CT scan.

Initial management involves keeping the patient nil per-oral, IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and analgesics. 

If there is no strangulation or peritonitis, it can be managed by:

  • Milking the stone beyond the ileocaecal junction
  • Crushing the stone
  • Enterotomy to remove the stone

If there is perforation or strangulation, resection and anastomosis are done.

Cholecystectomy and fistula closure is done after 4-6 weeks as the second procedure to avoid future complications. 

Given below is a plain X-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).

A large gallstone causing gallstone ileus is shown below.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the surgery OPD with a constellation of features like impotence, buttock claudication, and absence of the femoral pulses. These features are seen in __________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Leriche syndrome.

Leriche syndrome is a rare form of aorto-iliac Occlusive Disease (AIOD) which presents with a triad of intermittent claudication, erectile dysfunction, and absent femoral pulses. Obstruction of the superficial femoral artery will cause claudication of the buttock or thigh. Associated or isolated discomfort of the calf can also be seen because the calf is the most distal large muscle group and is used extensively in walking.

The other options correspond to sound alike signs/syndromes.

Option A: Leigh syndrome: is an inherited neurodegenerative condition. It usually becomes apparent in infancy, often after a viral infection. Early symptoms may include poor sucking ability; loss of head control and motor skills; loss of appetite; vomiting; and seizures. As the condition progresses, symptoms may include weakness and lack of muscle tone, spasticity, movement disorders, cerebellar ataxia and peripheral neuropathy.

Option B: Lhermitte's sign: Shooting electric shock-like sensations in the lower extremities when the neck is maximally flexed in patients with cervical radiculopathy.

Option C: Lemierre’s syndrome is septic thrombophlebitis in the internal jugular vein. This is a rare and potentially fatal complication of an oropharyngeal infection. The organism is typically a fusiform bacillus. Presents with severe neck pain, septicemia, or a prolonged fulminant course in a patient with infection in the upper aerodigestive tract.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient presents with symptoms of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and gastrinoma with cutaneous angiofibromas. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of MEN 1 syndrome.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes are characterized by tumors of two or more endocrine glands. There are four major types of MEN (MEN 1–4), and they either show an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance or occur sporadically. 

MEN 1, also known as Wermer’s syndrome, is characterized by the triad of parathyroid, pancreatic islet cell, and anterior pituitary tumors. Adrenal cortical tumors, carcinoid tumors, facial angiofibromas, collagenomas, thyroid tumors, and lipomas may also occur. MEN 1-associated tumors are usually multiple, larger, and more aggressive, resulting in resistance to treatment and poor patient outcomes.

  1. Parathyroid tumors- primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common feature of MEN 1. Hypercalcemia with or without symptoms (polyuria, polydipsia, constipation, dyspepsia), nephrolithiasis, and osteitis fibrosa cystica may also occur. All four parathyroid glands are usually affected with multiple adenomas or hyperplasia. 
  2. Pancreatic islet cell tumors- these are neuroendocrine tumors, including:
    • Gastrinoma (gastrin-secreting tumors)- associated with increased gastric acid secretion and multiple peptic ulcers (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). Patients may present with diarrhea and steatorrhea. Gastrinomas are the major cause of mortality and morbidity. 
    • Insulinoma (insulin-secreting tumors)- patients present with hypoglycemic symptoms (weakness, headaches, sweating, seizures, weight gain) that develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake. Along with increased plasma insulin levels and hypoglycemia, increased C peptide and proinsulin levels help in diagnosing the condition.
    • Glucagonoma (glucagon-secreting tumors)- may be associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, anemia, and stomatitis. 
    • VIPomas (Vasoactive intestinal peptide [VIP]-secreting tumors): The VIPoma syndrome, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. These are mostly located in the tail of the pancreas.
    • PPomas (Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting tumors) and nonfunctioning pancreatic tumors- are associated with a worse prognosis as they often go undiagnosed due to the absence of both clinical features and biochemical abnormalities.
  3. Pituitary tumors- manifestations depend on the hormone secreted (symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, or Cushing’s disease) and tumor size (visual disturbances or hypopituitarism due to compression of the optic chiasm or normal pituitary tissue). 

Surgical excision of the nonmetastatic tumor after localization is the curative treatment. Appropriate medical therapy can be used for some tumors when surgery is contraindicated or unsuccessful (calcimemetics for parathyroid tumors, parietal cell H+-K+-ATPase inhibitors for gastrinomas). In case of metastasis, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, radiation therapy, and artery embolization may be successful.

MEN 1 occurs due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene located on chromosome 11q13. Mutational genetic analysis is necessary to confirm the clinical diagnosis and identify family members who harbor the mutation and require screening for tumor detection and early treatment.

Other options:

Options B and C: MEN 2, also called Sipple’s syndrome, is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumors. This occurs due to mutations of the rearranged during transfection (RET) protooncogene. There are three clinical variants -

  1. MEN 2A (most common): MTC is associated with pheochromocytomas in 50% of patients and parathyroid tumors in 20% of patients. MEN 2A may also be associated with Hirschsprung’s disease and cutaneous lichen amyloidosis.
  2. MEN 2B (MEN 3): MTC is associated with pheochromocytoma, along with Marfanoid habitus; mucosal neuromas of the lips, tongue, and eyelids; medullated corneal fibers; and intestinal autonomic ganglion dysfunction leading to multiple diverticulae and megacolon. Parathyroid tumors are usually absent.
  3. MTC only (FMTC): MTC is the only manifestation.

Option D: MEN 4 is characterized by a combination of MEN 1–associated tumors and CDKN1B mutation-related tumors (gonadal, adrenal, renal, and thyroid tumors).

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: A newborn presents with anuria, and further evaluation reveals renal agenesis and pulmonary hypoplasia. There is also a history of oligohydramnios. The most probable diagnosis is _________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Potter syndrome.

Potter syndrome is characterized by the triad of :

  • Renal agenesis
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia

Due to oligohydramnios and small uterine cavity, they also have facial dysmorphisms and limb deformities.

Other options:

Option B: Pierre–Robin syndrome: Micrognathia, Retrognathia, Glossoptosis.

Option C: Downs syndrome is Trisomy 21 is the most common genetic cause of moderate intellectual disability. It is associated with many congenital anomalies and characteristic dysmorphic features.

Option D: CHARGE syndrome is characterised by presence of, Coloboma of the eye, Heart anomaly, Choanal Atresia, Retardation, Genital and Ear anomalies.

questions.text: A 3-day-old infant is brought with a rash. On examination, chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions are noted, with no cardiovascular abnormality. CT head shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this infant with periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly is congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

CMV is the most common congenital infection. The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Diagnosis can be made by the presence of IgM antibodies in the fetal blood. Isolation of the virus from the urine or blood by PCR is more sensitive.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness. Below is the image showing the blueberry muffin baby.

Other options:

Option A- Congenital rubella syndrome is due to the rubella virus. The classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome are deafness, cataract and congenital heart disease. Patent ductus arteriosus is the common cardiac defect. Eye findings also include salt and pepper retinopathy as shown below.

Option B- Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. Early features include hepato-splenomegaly, jaundice, diffuse lymphadenopathy, maculopapular or vesiculobullous rash involving hands and feet, persistent rhinitis (snuffles), and condylomatous lesions. 

Skeletal changes like saber shins, dental abnormalities like Hutchinson's teeth, and saddle nose - depression of the nasal root are some late findings.

Option C- Congenital toxoplasmosis is due to Toxoplasma gondii. A classic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications is seen. Blueberry muffin baby appearance is also seen in this. Calcifications occur randomly throughout the brain in congenital toxoplasmosis while periventricular calcification is characteristic of congenital CMV infection.

questions.text: A patient with a history of viral fever presents with symptoms and is diagnosed with an acquired nerve disease, which is a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome. All of the following symptoms are part of its triad except?
questions.solution:
Weakness is not seen in the triad of Miller-Fisher syndrome (MFS)

Miller Fisher syndrome is an acquired nerve disease that is considered to be a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome. Like Guillain-Barré syndrome, symptoms may be preceded by a viral illness.

Classically presents as a triad of: Ataxia, Areflexia and Ophthalmoplegia. The condition is usually not associated with weakness, if present, is very mild. It is strongly associated with antibodies to the ganglioside.

The prognosis for most individuals with Miller Fisher syndrome is good. In most cases, recovery begins within 2 to 4 weeks of the onset of symptoms, and may be almost complete within 6 months. Some individuals are left with residual deficits. Relapses may occur rarely.

Treatment for Miller Fisher syndrome is identical to treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome: intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis and supportive care.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents with severe chest pain that began the previous night. She reports binge drinking at a party, followed by several episodes of vomiting, some of which were mixed with blood. On examination, she appears unwell, has rapid breathing, a blood pressure of 90/50 mm Hg, a heart rate of 112/min, and palpable crepitus. An X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described, featuring a triad of symptoms including recurrent episodes of vomiting with blood, along with new onset chest pain and palpable crepitus, and an X-ray revealing pneumomediastinum, is indicative of Boerhaave’s Syndrome.
 
Boerhaave's syndrome is a transmural perforation of the esophagus (while Mallory Weiss's tear is a mucosal tear). It generally occurs due to forceful vomiting against a closed glottis. It clinically presents with classical Mackler's triad of vomiting, chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema. The lower esophagus towards the left pleural cavity is the most common perforation site. A crunching sound is heard during the auscultation of the chest (Hamman's sign) due to subcutaneous emphysema.

The diagnosis is made by contrast esophagogram(iohexol) in unstable patients or contrast-enhanced CT scan, in stable patients.

Treatment includes primary closure within 12 hours of the injury for a better prognosis. If the patient is unstable or presents late, the perforated part is resected, and a cervical esophagostomy is performed. A T-tube is placed into the esophagus along with appropriately located drains and a feeding jejunostomy or gastrostomy is performed for nutrition.

Other options

Option A: Pneumothorax is an abnormal collection of air in the pleural space between the lung and the chest wall. Symptoms typically include sudden onset of sharp, one-sided chest pain and shortness of breath.

Option C:  Acute chest syndrome is characterised by acute chest pain, hypoxemia and pulmonary infiltrates on chest radiograph. It is an acute vaso-occlusion crisis in patients with sickle cell anemia which occur spontaneously or is triggered by infection, dehydration or hypoxia.

Options D: Mallory-Weiss tear is characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction, typically following forceful vomiting. It usually presents with hematemesis and epigastric pain but does not typically cause severe chest pain or crepitus. The endoscopy finding of Mallory-Weiss tear is given below.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with the loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is also lost. The lesion is most likely located at?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome which occurs due to a lesion located at lateral pons.

Lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestations include:
    • CN VII: Facial paralysis 
    • CN V: loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face.
    • Vestibular nerve or nucleus: Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia.
    • Auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus: Deafness, tinnitus.
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.
  • Contralateral manifestations include:
    • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body.

 Note:

In this clinical vignette, due to the absence of characteristic features specific to lateral medullary syndrome, like dysphagia and hoarseness of voice (involvement of 9th and 10th cranial nerves), the lesion is most likely to be located at lateral pons (lateral pontine syndrome) and not lateral medulla.

questions.text: A 10-month-old female baby with an abdominal mass is diagnosed with Wilm's tumor. On examination, the following findings are seen in the baby. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given images  show macroglossia and omphalocele which when considered with the Wilm's tumor points to the diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an example of a disorder of genomic imprinting. The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is in chromosome 11 (band p15.5) distal to the WT1 locus. It is characterized by-

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Macrosomia
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihyperplasia
  • Omphalocele
  • Visceromegaly
  • Embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other presentations of Wilm's tumor include hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, and tumor rupture causing acute abdomen. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs.

On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

The below image shows macroglossia seen in a baby diagnosed with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

Other options-

Option A: WAGR is a contiguous gene syndrome that is characterized by Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and mental retardation.

Option B: Sturge-Weber syndrome is also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis. It is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angioma of the face, choroid, and leptomeninges. In the facial territory of the trigeminal nerve capillary, a vascular malformation called port-wine stain or nevus flammeus is usually seen. 

Option C: Denys-Drash syndrome presents with early-onset nephrotic syndrome, progressive renal insufficiency, ambiguous genitalia, and Wilms tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following structures are involved in the unhappy triad?
questions.solution:
The unhappy triad of O’Donoghue consists of injury to

  • Anterior cruciate ligament (A)
  • Medial collateral ligament (B)
  • Medial meniscus (C)

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called as – O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to lateral blow to the knee. It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

Image: Unhappy triad injury in MRI (after O'Donoghue) of the knee joint (PDW SPIR). Left to right: Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament, rupture of the medial collateral ligament, and inner meniscal tear (here complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: A 4-year-old female child is currently under evaluation for supra-valvular aortic stenosis and mental retardation. A characteristic facies is present as shown in the image below. Her karyotype reveals 46XX and her blood investigations reveal hypercalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of mental retardation, elfin facies, hypercalcemia, and supravalvular aortic stenosis is strongly suggestive of Williams syndrome.

The image shows a young girl with an elfin face with a round face, full cheeks, broad nasal bridge, anteverted nares, thick lips, and a large mouth that is usually left open. They also have short palpebral fissures, prominent ears, and a small mandible. 

It is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple congenital development defects, including supra-valvular aortic stenosis, mental retardation, and an elfin facies, in association with hypercalcemia due to abnormal sensitivity to vitamin D with elevated levels of 1,25(OH)2D ranging from 150 to 500 pg/mL. It is caused by genetic mutations involving microdeletions at the elastin locus on chromosome 7. 

Other options:

Option A: DiGeorge syndrome is caused due to deletion of chromosome 22q11.2. The characteristic features are (Mnemonic CATCH-22) Cardiac abnormality, abnormal facies, thymic aplasia, cleft palate, hypocalcemia.

The following image shows a child with DiGeorge syndrome:

Option C : Down syndrome occurs due to trisomy of chromosome 21 leading to multisystem manifestations. A few key features include characteristic facies such as flat face, epicanthal folds, small head, flat nasal bridge, upward slanting palpebral fissues, brushfield spots, small nose, protruding tongue, small and lowset ears. Congenital heart defects can also be present.

The following image shows a child with Down syndrome:

Option D: Edward syndrome is a trisomy of chromosome 18. It is characterized by microcephaly, microphthalmia, prominent nasal bridge, coloboma of iris, microretrognathia, cleft lip, cleft palate, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and severe growth retardation. 

The following image shows a child with Edward syndrome, note the clenched fist with overlapping fingers:

questions.text: After an acute attack of angle closure glaucoma the patient develops the following triad of symptoms except?
questions.solution:
Vogt's triad is seen after an acute attack of primary angle-closure Glaucoma. It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil. Glaukomflecken is used to describe an anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity. The slightly dilated pupil is attributed to sphincter atrophy.

Glaucoma is used to describe a group of conditions where there is progressive optic neuropathy with irreversible visual field defects associated with raised intraocular pressure. It can be classified into congenital/developmental glaucomas, primary adult glaucomas, and secondary adult glaucomas.

Primary adult glaucomas are of three types:

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG)
  • Primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG)
  • Primary mixed mechanism glaucoma. 

 In primary angle-closure disease, there is apposition of the peripheral iris with the trabecular meshwork. This interferes with the drainage of aqueous humor. It is seen more commonly in elderly females. Anatomical risk factors include hypermetropic eyes, anteriorly placed iris-lens diaphragm, and a narrow-angle of the anterior chamber. The international society of geographical and epidemiological opthalmology (ISGEO) has classified primary angle-closure disease into three types.

PACS and PAC are seen before the development of PACG. Vogt triad is seen after an acute attack of PAC.

PAC includes irido-trabecular contact on gonioscopy and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) and/or peripheral anterior synechiae. The optic disc and visual fields are usually normal. Due to any reason, there can be an acute rise of IOP in patients with PAC. It is a vision-threatening emergency and the sequelae of which can be ciliary body shut down, Vogt's triad, and rarely spontaneous angle reopening.

questions.text: A 35-year-old  woman takes aspirin for a headache, later she presented with wheezing and breathlessness. These symptoms are likely to be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of aspirin intolerance. It is most likely to be associated with nasal polyps. 

In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided due to the risk of the development of aspirin intolerance.

Samter triad is a non-IgE mediated hypersensitivity reaction associated with the intake of aspirin or other cyclooxygenase inhibitors. Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

Patients with Samter's triad will have persistent nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, anosmia, nasal polyps, and recurrent chronic rhinosinusitis. Asthma and aspirin intolerance develop later.

Acute asthma attacks usually occur 3 hours after intake of aspirin or NSAIDs. Severe rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur. 

Patients should avoid aspirin and NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1. Treatment may involve aspirin desensitization and endoscopic sinus surgery.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with complaints of urinary incontinence. His history is notable for increasing forgetfulness and the physical examination reveals an abnormal gait. His fundus looks normal, he has no tremors.  Which of the following conditions is it most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario the probable diagnosis is normal pressure hydrocephalus. 

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is a reversible cause of dementia, typically presenting with the classic triad of dementia, ataxia, and urinary incontinence. With early diagnosis and prompt treatment, symptoms can often be reversed.

NPH occurs due to impaired cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow and delayed absorption, often resulting from scarring of the basilar meninges. It is characterized by communicating hydrocephalus and the hallmark triad (dementia, ataxia, and urinary incontinence). Papilledema is not observed. Neuroimaging typically reveals enlarged lateral ventricles with little or no cortical atrophy, while the Sylvian fissures may appear enlarged, a phenomenon known as "boxcarring," which can be confused with perisylvian atrophy. The preferred treatment is ventriculoperitoneal shunting, and CSF parameters are generally normal.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

CONDITION FEATURES
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus &/or seizures

questions.text: You are following up on a patient who is suspected to have Gradenigo's syndrome. Which of the following will not constitute a component of the classical triad of this condition?
questions.solution:
Gradenigo’s Syndrome generally occurs secondary to petrous apicitis. It is a complication of the attico-antral type of otitis media. Immobility of the homolateral soft palate (generally due to X cranial nerve palsy) is not a component of its classical triad of symptoms. 

Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy) - lateral rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain (V nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

Fever, headache, vomiting and sometimes neck rigidity may also be associated. Some patients may get facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo due to the involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves.

Diagnosis of petrous apicitis requires both a CT scan and an MRI. CT scan of temporal bone will show bony details of the petrous apex and the air cells while MRI helps to differentiate diploic marrow-containing apex from the fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Other options:
Option B: Trotter’s Triad is seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It consists of:

  1. Conductive hearing loss
  2. Immobility of homolateral soft palate
  3. Trigeminal neuralgia

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of palpitations, headache, and sweating. Her blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg, heart rate is 135/min. CT abdomen shows a suprarenal mass. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. Her mother had renal cell carcinoma. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of pheochromocytoma along with the h/o renal cell carcinoma is suggestive of Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease.

The given clinical picture is suggestive of pheochromocytoma and it may be associated with all the listed syndromes: MEN 2B(Marfanoid habitus), von Hippel Lindau syndrome (renal cell carcinoma), and medullary carcinoma thyroid (MEN 2A and 2B).

Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease:

  • It is an inherited, autosomal dominant syndrome(chromosome 3).
  • It is manifested by a variety of benign and malignant tumors which include hemangioblastomas, clear cell renal cell carcinomas (RCCs), and pheochromocytomas.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever and calf pain for the past 2 months. He had undergone knee replacement surgery 3 months ago, and a diagnosis of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is confirmed with duplex scan. Regarding the disease’s pathophysiology, Virchow’s triad includes all of the following except _________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of deep venous thrombosis(DVT) and the Virchows triad includes all except, hyperviscosity.

In the given clinical scenario, a patient with a history of knee replacement surgery presents with fever and calf pain for 2 months, leading to a diagnosis of DVT, confirmed by a duplex scan. The pathophysiology of the disease involves Virchow’s triad, which includes endothelial injury, hypercoagulability and abnormal blood flow. Hyperviscosity is not part of Virchow’s triad; however, hyperviscosity conditions, such as polycythemia vera, can lead to small vessel stasis, which may contribute to thrombosis.

Virchow's triad in thrombosis:

  1. Endothelial integrity is the most important factor. Injury to endothelial cells can alter local blood flow and affect coagulability.
  2. Abnormal blood flow (stasis or turbulence), in turn, can cause endothelial injury.
  3. Hypercoagulability of blood

DVT most commonly occurs in the calf veins and less often in the proximal veins of the thigh and pelvis. Causes include:

  • Postoperative thrombosis- (Most common cause)Following childbirth
  • Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis
  • Muscular violence
  • Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis).
  • Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Features of DVT

  • Fever- commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s sign
  • Inverted champagne bottle sign

Moses sign - Squeezing of the relaxed calf muscles from side to side is also painful as the thrombosed deep veins in the calf are always tender and this test is known as Moses sign.

Homans sign - Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with the knee extended will elicit tenderness in the calf. Gentle pressure directly on the calf muscles in the relaxed position will also elicit pain. Care must be taken to be gentle in manipulation lest it may dislodge a clot and cause a pulmonary embolism. The image is attached below. 

Treatment: Rest, the elevation of the limb, and bandaging of the entire limb with crepe bandage. Anticoagulants like Heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, and phenindione. Palma and May-Husni operations are also done. 

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

questions.text: In which hamartoneoplastic syndrome is the following condition seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows a periungual fibroma or Koenen tumor, which is characteristic of tuberous sclerosis (autosomal dominant inheritance). They appear at or after puberty as smooth, firm, flesh-colored excrescences emerging from the nail folds. 

Tuberous sclerosis is a neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to mutations in the genes hamartin and tuberin on chromosomes 9 and 16, respectively. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion and presents with multiple cutaneous findings which are divided into major and minor features.

Major features :

Ash leaf macules -lance ovate shaped, hypopigmented lesions which are the earliest to manifest( at birth or early infancy)
Adenoma sebaceum - facial angiofibromas, which are the characteristics lesions of tuberous sclerosis. Usually appear between 3 to 10 years and become extensive at puberty
Shagreen patches - collagenomas which are leathery in texture and found in the lumbosacral region
Koenen tumors - periungual fibromas, with appear at or after puberty

Minor features :

Hypopigmented confetti macules
Dental enamel pits
Gingival fibromas

The central nervous system lesions include cortical tubers, subependymal nodules and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas.The other systemic manifestations are renal angiomyolipoma, cardiac rhabdomyoma and pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis.

Other options:

Option B: Lynch syndrome is the most common inherited cause of colonic cancer (right colon). Inherited mutations of genes MSH2 or MLH1 leading to defective DNA mismatch repair results in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer. It is mainly associated with early-onset endometrial cancer, urothelial cancers of renal pelvis and cutaneous manifestations such as sebaceous adenomas.

Option C: Cowden’s syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by familial germline loss of function mutation of the tumor suppressor gene, PTEN on chromosome 10 resulting in increased PI3K/AKT pathway signalling. It predisposes to various epithelial tumours.

Epithelial tumours associated with Cowden’s syndrome are multiple hamartomatous GI polyps, breast cancer, endometrial cancer and thyroid cancer. Mucocutaneous manifestations of the syndrome include facial trichilemmomas which is a benign appendageal tumor, oral mucosal papillomatosis showing cobblestone appearance, acral keratosis and palmoplantar keratosis.

Option D: Gardner syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) syndrome is associated with hepatoblastoma. Activation of WNT signalling plays a major role in hepatoblastomas. This occurs by a variety of mechanisms including mutations in APC gene. Hence, patients with FAP syndromes frequently develop hepatoblastomas.

Related Pearl: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.
